summary: None

headline: Bin Laden's Compound
summary: A look at diagrams provided by U.S. officials show the walled property where the raid took place.

summary: What's News: World-Wide

headline: Australia Grants Exchange License to Chi-X
summary: Australia's government granted a full securities-exchange license to Chi-X, setting the stage for the first direct competitor to the Australian Securities Exchange to come on line later this year.

headline: Financial Briefing Book: May 4
summary: Financial Briefing Book: May 4

headline: Morning News Roundup
summary: News roundup from Indian newspapers, news wires and Web sites on Wednesday, May 4, 2011. Deals India has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

headline: Investors Pledge $3.1 Billion for Glencore IPO
summary: Glencore International has secured $3.1 billion in cornerstone investments from a diverse group that includes sovereign-wealth funds from Abu Dhabi and Singapore, asset-management firms, hedge funds and private banks.

headline: Yankees, Mets Both Lose
summary: Detroit roughs up CC Sabathia for four runs and 10 hits to score a 4-2 win, while the Giants beat the Mets after New York fails to score with the bases loaded in the bottom of the ninth inning.

headline: Dabur Buys 30-Plus Brand
summary: Dabur India has entered into an agreement with Mumbai-based Ajanta Pharma to acquire its over-the-counter '30-Plus' brand for an undisclosed amount.

headline: Macau Gambling Revenue Surges 45%
summary: Gambling revenue in Macau rose 45% in April from a year earlier, as mainland Chinese visitors to the world's largest gambling market helped push the results to a third straight monthly record.

headline: China's Destabilizing Inequity
summary: It's not just social stability that is at risk from China's wealth divide. If China's rich head for the door the financial system could take a hit as well.

headline: Sony Faces German Data Questions
summary: German privacy officials demand that Sony explain its handling of sensitive data following the theft of client data, a German state-government privacy official said.

headline: India Makes Exits Easier for Foreign Investors
summary: A rule put in place last year on the pricing of convertible instruments that made it difficult for foreign private equity and venture capital funds to invest in Indian companies, because it meant a fixed exit price, was scrapped recently.

headline: One Expensive Bankruptcy Case
summary: An old adage says it is expensive to go broke. It sure was for mall owner General Growth Properties, which has been presented with a bill for $229.2 million in fees and $6.5 million in reimbursements.

headline: EXL to Buy Outsource Partners for $91 Million
summary: Nasdaq-listed outsourcing company EXL Service Holdings has agreed to acquire Outsource Partners International for $91 million.

headline: Conrad to Propose New Debt Plan
summary: The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee said he would lay out a proposal for a 2012 budget and long-term debt reduction plan that aims to change policies so that the U.S. runs up $4 trillion less in deficits over 10 years than it otherwise would.

headline: Disney, Starz Sue Dish
summary: Walt Disney's Disney Enterprises Inc. is suing a division of Dish Network in federal court, alleging Dish is violating Disney copyrights by offering Starz programming free to Dish subscribers.

headline: Daniel Alegre: Valuing the Internet
summary: In freewheeling Hong Kong, the Internet economy was worth 5.9% of GDP in 2009.

headline: Cerberus Team Wins Hotel Auction
summary: A team of private-equity firm Cerberus Capital Management and real-estate investment trust Chatham Lodging Trust prevailed in a bankruptcy auction for 64 of Innkeepers USA Trust's hotels.

headline: Wells Holders Vote on Splitting Top Jobs
summary: Shareholders of Wells Fargo cast 30% of their votes for separating the jobs of chairman and chief executive after an influential proxy advisory firm questioned the lead outside director's independence.

headline: At the Met Ball, Oscar Night for the Fashion Set
summary: The Metropolitan Museum of Art hosted its annual Costume Institute benefit Monday night, an event that's been called Oscar Night for the fashion community. The event marks the opening of Savage Beauty, an exhibit of Alexander McQueen's iconic designs.

headline: New Drug Used in Texas Execution
summary: Texas became the third state to use a sedative long used to euthanize animals to carry out a lethal injection.

headline: 'Outrageous' Violations Found at Massey Mine
summary: Mining regulators found multiple safety violations at a West Virginia mine owned by Massey, saying the conditions were "nothing short of outrageous."

headline: Cash Crunch Won't Rush L.A.'s MLB Monitor
summary: The Los Angeles Dodgers may not have enough cash to cover their expenses at the end of this month and will face insolvency by July, according to two people familiar with the team's financial problems.

headline: Pakistan Criticizes U.S. Raid on bin Laden
summary: Pakistan said Tuesday it had "concerns and reservations" about Washington's decision to attack and kill al Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden deep inside Pakistan without seeking their permission or giving forewarning. But a Pakistani official said it hadn't lodged complaints with the U.S.

headline: Australia Warns of Rising Inflation
summary: Australia's central bank left interest rates on hold, but it also signaled a policy tightening isn't far off as inflation looks set to rise further.

headline: Euro-Zone Data Show Inflation Risk
summary: Factory-gate prices in the euro zone posted their sharpest annual gain for two-and-a-half years in March, putting more pressure on the European Central Bank to tighten monetary policy further.

headline: Pfizer Drags on Blue Chips
summary: Blue-chip stocks finished virtually unchanged as investors dumped energy and materials stocks and headed for the safety of bonds and telecommunications companies

headline: China Deepens Corporate Bond Market
summary: China has issued rules allowing nonfinancial companies to sell bonds via private placement, marking the country's latest effort to deepen its corporate bond market.

headline: How to Criticize Your Boss -- Nicely
summary: A reader wonders how to tell his boss that he uses too many catch phrases in conversation. Turns out, there's a right way and a wrong way to offer constructive criticism to your  superior.

headline: BNY Mellon Global Markets Chief to Retire; No Link to FX Probes
summary: Richard Mahoney, a top Bank of New York Mellon executive in charge of global markets, is retiring at the end of June, according to an internal memo. His unit includes a forex business that is the focus of state probes and litigation, but his move isn't linked to the pending matters.

headline: MasterCard's Strong Earnings Spur Options Bets on Visa
summary: After MasterCard's strong earnings report, options traders are placing bets on a similar showing from Visa when the card company reports Thursday.

headline: NYSE Won't Press Deal Ahead of Review
summary: The head of NYSE Euronext said that the exchange operator and Deutsche Börse won't seek to "front-run" regulators in seeking approval for their planned merger.

headline: Silver Trade Showing a Wilder Side
summary: A 12% tumble made headlines, but doesn't tell the whole story on what has been a remarkably volatile week for the gray metal.

headline: MasterCard Profit Rises 24%
summary: MasterCard's first-quarter profit rose 24%, topping analysts' expectations, and revenue also beat views.

headline: ADM Profit Climbs 37%
summary: Archer Daniels Midland's fiscal third-quarter earnings rose 37% amid gains at the grain-processing giant's oilseeds- and corn-processing businesses.

headline: Bogota Mayor Suspended Amid Contracts Scandal
summary: Bogota Mayor Samuel Moreno was suspended by Colombia's solicitor general amid a corruption probe that has already led to the arrest of the mayor's brother.

headline: Steeler Causes Stir With bin Laden Tweets
summary: Rashard Mendenhall has created a controversy with comments made on his official Twitter page regarding Osama bin Laden's death.

headline: Supervalu to Unveil New Private-Label Brand
summary: The fourth-largest food retailer by sales will replace existing store brands with a new 'Essential Everyday' label as American consumers show an increased appetite for private-label goods.

headline: Oil Ends Below $112
summary: Crude-oil futures tumbled as traders focused on a plunge in silver prices and signs of weakening U.S. demand for fuel.

headline: Nuclear Tests Draw Scrutiny in EU
summary: Differences among European Union countries on whether to test the safety of nuclear plants in the case of an airplane crash surfaced days before the EU is expected to make public new safety criteria under "stress tests."

headline: Shanghai Pharma Leads New IPO Rush
summary: Shanghai Pharmaceuticals leads three companies seeking nearly $3 billion from Hong Kong investors this month alone, adding to a surge of IPOs in coming weeks just as the market shows new signs of flagging.

headline: Shell to Apply for Alaska Offshore-Drilling Permit
summary: A Shell Oil spokesman said Tuesday the company plans to apply on Wednesday for a federal permit to drill for oil in the Beaufort Sea off the Alaskan shore.

headline: Photos of the Day: May 3
summary: In today's pictures, sailors salute at Boston's Fenway Park, members of indigenous tribes meet in Brazil, a tornado tears through park of New Zealand and more.

headline: Microsoft, RIM Strike Search Deal
summary: Microsoft said its Bing search engine and mapping service will be the default  options for Research In Motion's BlackBerry devices.

headline: Tongue Twisted
summary: None

headline: ProLogis Bidders Aim Low
summary: In the takeover battle for ProLogis European Properties, the offers submitted so far don't reflect the possibility of a recovery in Europe's industrial market pushing the value of the company higher.

headline: Earnings Weigh on Europe Stocks
summary: European stock markets fell, led by auto makers, as disappointing earnings from blue-chip companies and renewed worries about European sovereign debt discouraged investors.

headline: Indian Shares Tumble, Leading Asian Swoon
summary: India's Sensex dropped 2.4% after the central bank raised interest rates. Australian shares lost ground on dour profit outlooks for ANZ and Fairfax Media.

headline: Hermès Sells Stake in Gaultier Label
summary: France's Hermès International said it has sold its 45% stake in fashion label Jean-Paul Gaultier to Spain's Grupo Puig for €16 million.

headline: U.K. Accounting Groups Say Oil-Tax Rise Poses Risk
summary: The U.K.'s key accounting bodies said Tuesday the recent surprise increase in taxation on North Sea oil and gas production risks damaging the country's competitiveness.

summary: Hedge-fund manager Och-Ziff Capital Management reported a widened first-quarter net loss as earnings remained hampered by charges related to its 2007 initial public offering, but said its "distributable earnings" rose 33% on higher management fees.

headline: Apple Updates iMac With New Intel Chips
summary: Apple updated its iMac desktop computers with next-generation Intel processors and the chip company's high-speed data-transfer technology, following similar upgrades to MacBook notebooks.

summary: Ally Financial's first-quarter earnings fell 9.9% as profitability in its North American auto-finance and mortgage operations declined.

headline: Nasdaq Explains Raft of Canceled Trades
summary: Nasdaq OMX Group said a brokerage's bad order in a basket of health-care companies prompted exchanges to cancel trades in more than 50 stocks in after-hours trading on Monday evening.

headline: Saab Signs Funding Deal
summary: Saab Automobile reached an investment agreement with Chinese auto maker Hawtai Motor Group that could enable the ailing Swedish car maker to restart production as soon as next week.

headline: Greek Restructuring Isn't Straightforward
summary: Markets are betting on a Greek debt restructuring sooner rather than later. But a restructuring might be harder to achieve than some suggest.

headline: Fatalities as Tornado Hits New Zealand
summary: A tornado killed shoppers in Auckland, New Zealand, adding to woes in a country still struggling to recover from a devastating earthquake earlier this year.

headline: Bain Set to Bid for Micro Focus
summary: U.S. buyout firm Bain Capital is poised to bid for British software company Micro Focus International, a person familiar with the situation said.

headline: U.K. Data Suggests Weakness

headline: Vietnam Trims Growth Forecast
summary: Vietnam trimmed its 2011 economic growth forecast and sharply raised its inflation expectations, as the government faces an ongoing battle to restore economic stability.

headline: Sirius Profit Up 88%
summary: Sirius XM Radio said profit jumped 88% on a 9% increase in revenue as it added subscribers.

headline: VW Keen to Expand Truck Arm
summary: Volkswagen said the heavy-truck and bus segment is a "highly attractive strategic business area" and reiterated the German auto maker's desire to become the world's leading automotive company.

summary: U.S. factory sector orders rose for the fifth consecutive month in March and capital spending by businesses surged as manufacturers sell to overseas markets.

headline: Man Group Raises $1.5 Billion

headline: Avon Profit Leaps
summary: Avon profit more than tripled as the cosmetics company's sales and margins improved and advertising costs fell.

headline: Sensex Tumbles, Leading Asian Declines
summary: Indian stocks tumbled after the central bank raised interest rates more than expected, but Chinese stocks edged higher after data indicated that manufacturing growth in China had slowed, easing concerns of further monetary tightening there.

summary: Daimler introduced its GL 500 sport-utility vehicle and SL 350 sedan in India's rapidly expanding market for super luxury automobiles where it trails German peer BMW.

headline: CME April Volume Up 1.7%
summary: CME Group's daily trading volume rose 1.7% in April, the exchange operator said Tuesday, as surging commodities and metals activity was tempered by muted trading of other products.

summary: The hats came out for the wedding ceremony of Prince William and Catherine Middleton

headline: Firstsource to Buy Stake in Sri Lankan Firm

summary: Australia & New Zealand Banking Group posted a 38% rise in first-half profit, but warned that lending growth will slow.

headline: Osama Bin Laden Is Dead

headline: Bananas Boost Fresh Del Monte Profit
summary: Fresh Del Monte Produce's first-quarter earnings rose 52%, beating analysts' estimates, as the fruit and vegetable producer benefited from higher banana prices amid production shortages.

headline: Marico in Talks on Potential Purchases
summary: Marico, the Indian consumer goods maker, is in early talks to buy companies both in India and abroad, and may raise funds through equity or debt offerings to finance a potential buy.

headline: Osama bin Laden Is Dead
summary: Al Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden is dead, President Obama said.

headline: China Housing Inflation Slows
summary: Residential property prices in 100 major cities in China were up 0.40% in April from March, less than March's 0.59% increase, China Real Estate Index System said.

headline: France Telecom Backs Forecast
summary: France Telecom confirmed its full-year outlook despite heightened competitive pressure in its home market, as it posted a 1.3% decline in its earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization.

headline: Strong Currency Lifts Korean Air's Profit

summary: German chip maker Infineon said fiscal second-quarter profit jumped on a gain from the sale of its mobile communication business, and raised its full-year outlook for the second time as demand in the remaining units remains healthy.

summary: Years of work were involved in tracking down Osama bin Laden, the elusive al Qaeda leader and the architect of the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks.

headline: Osama bin Laden Is Dead
summary: Al Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden is dead, President Obama said. Bin Laden was killed in a joint raid in northwestern Pakistan overnight Sunday. The development capped a manhunt of more than a decade for the architect of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks that left nearly 3,000 people dead and dramatically altered U.S. foreign policy and the nation's sense of security.

headline: Southeast Asia Braces for Islamist Reprisals
summary: Officials around Southeast Asia are watching out for potential reprisals from Islamist terrorist groups around the region following news of Osama bin Laden's death.

headline: Massey Swings to Loss on Higher Expenses
summary: Massey swung to a first-quarter loss as the coal miner reported higher costs and expenses, masking better-than-expected revenue growth as production and shipments grew.

headline: Companies Bid to Develop India Coal Mine
summary: A unit of Australia's Leighton Holdings and India's Singareni Collieries are among about half a dozen companies that have bid to develop power producer NTPC's Chatti-Bariatu coal mine in the eastern state of Jharkhand.

headline: Can Fletcher Be a Leader of Champions?
summary: The challenges facing India's new cricket coach include a demanding fan base, insatiable media and all-time greats expected to retire soon.

headline: Caramel Crunch and More
summary: Remember your first bite of caramel crunch cake? The popular sweet was first introduced in Hong Kong by fashionista Bonnie Gokson, the owner of Sevva restaurant. The socialite's newest food shop is meant to satisfy the sweet tooth of her loyal fans with 15 newly developed cakes.

headline: Corps Blows Hole Through Levee
summary: The Army Corps of Engineers blew a nearly two-mile gap in a Missouri levee to ease record flooding where the Ohio River spills into the Mississippi, activating a decades-old flood plan that had been contested all the way to the U.S Supreme Court.

headline: Government Mortgage Guarantees Have Their Place
summary: We agree with Peter J. Wallison ("Government Mortgage Guarantees Are Unnecessary," op-ed, April 21) However, I can unequivocally say that, for the foreseeable future, a private market only solution is impractical for rental housing.

headline: Business Watch
summary: Here is a selection of business news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: The Muslim World After Bin Laden
summary: Despite much promise, Egypt's new start shows real perils ahead.

headline: What Gives Social Norms Their Power
summary: Psychologists are studying how social norms, the often-unspoken rules of a group, shape not just our behavior but also our attitudes.

headline: Grilled Cheese Has Trendy Rebirth
summary: The annual Grilled Cheese Invitational, which attracts fans eager to display novel takes on the ultimate American comfort food, is a testament to the nation's grilled-cheese renaissance.

headline: Air Canada Tries New Approach
summary: Air Canada has embarked on a campaign to persuade American business travelers to fly through Toronto and other Canadian hubs on their way abroad.

headline: Rule Over Abuse of IPOs Delayed
summary: A regulatory rule to prevent abuse of initial public offerings has been delayed, even as Wall Street gears up for a new round of Internet-company IPOs.

headline: Threat From Splinter Groups Persists
summary: Long before Osama bin Laden's death, his al Qaeda terror network had adapted itself to survive and operate without him, ensuring that the threat it poses will live well beyond his demise.

headline: Quest for Vaccines to Treat Addiction
summary: A look at the research behind vaccines to treat people addicted to cigarettes, heroin and cocaine.

headline: Germany Gets New Inflation Cop
summary: Economist Jens Weidmann officially began his term as the youngest-ever president of Germany's central bank, vowing to carry on the rigorous anti-inflation philosophy of his predecessor, Axel Weber.

headline: Nasdaq, ICE Take NYSE Bid to Investors
summary: Nasdaq OMX Group and ICE announced their intent to go hostile with their $11 billion takeover offer for NYSE Euronext.

summary: A project to install air filters to reduce airborne radiation at one of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear complex's reactors began, in a move aimed at allowing workers to enter the building to make needed repairs.

headline: A Designer for the Closet, Not Just the Museum
summary: Alexander McQueen was famous for his runway extravagance. But were everyday New Yorkers actually wearing his clothes?

headline: Japan Car Makers Reel
summary: New auto sales in Japan posted a record drop in April, as a parts shortage caused by the March 11 earthquake and tsunami cut into production of vehicles and reduced supplies to dealerships.

headline: PPR to Buy Surfwear Maker Volcom
summary: French luxury and retail group PPR said it is paying $608 million to buy  California sportswear brand Volcom, which will dovetail with its Puma division.

headline: Arch to Buy International Coal
summary: Arch Coal agreed to acquire International Coal Group for $3.4 billion, becoming the latest coal producer seeking to secure reserves and take advantage of rising prices in the red-hot international market for metallurgical coal used by steelmakers.

headline: Arch Coal Mines a Rich Seam
summary: Arch Coal is the latest miner to dig a tunnel abroad with its $3.5 billion takeover of International Coal Group. It won't be the last.

headline: Jason Riley: The Evidence Is In—School Vouchers Work
summary: A study published last year found that D.C. voucher recipients had graduation rates of 91%. That's significantly higher than the public school average of 56%.

summary: Studies show that having sex improves mood, sleep and cardiovascular health, among other things. But does sex make people healthier or do healthier people have more sex?

headline: Bigger Belly, Bigger Heart Risk
summary: A new study offers fresh evidence that belly fat is the chief culprit in the link between obesity and cardiovascular disease.

headline: High Earners Pay Growing Tax Share
summary: As President Obama pushes to raise taxes on high earners, opponents are seizing on data that suggests these U.S. households already pay a large and growing share of taxes, even compared with high-tax European countries.

headline: Link in Autism, Brain Size
summary: New research shows increased brain growth in children with autism occurs before age 2.

headline: Genetic Tests Should Include Interpretation
summary: The article "Your Genes in an Envelope? More, Please" (Review, April 23) mischaracterizes the American Medical Association's position.

headline: The Next Round Is on the King of Beers
summary: Despite price increases and sluggish sales in the developed world, first-quarter numbers should show the brewer of Budweiser beer still has some fizz.

headline: Headhunters Seek Larger Pool of Women Candidates
summary: Financial companies want more women in higher positions, and executive search companies are having to cast their net wider.

headline: Russia, India Consider Grain Exports
summary: Expectations of surplus grain in Russia and India are driving speculation that the two producers might resume exports, as global wheat prices soar. Grain dealers in Russia are starting to move stocks to ports in the hope that the government will allow exports as early as July.

headline: All That Twitters Is Not Gold
summary: It's being called Twitter's "CNN moment." But will it pay off for the site's investors?

headline: Season Affects Postpartum Depression
summary: Women who give birth during the fall and winter are twice as likely to suffer from postpartum depression than if they deliver in the spring, according to a study.

headline: Bin Laden Gone, But City Feels Threat
summary: As it has done repeatedly since 2001, New York again braced itself for the threat of terror. But it was less apparent whether the city is in the immediate crosshairs of al Qaeda operatives.

headline: Your Lawyer Should Cover Your Back
summary: Regarding your editorial "Knave and Spalding" (April 26): One wonders if King and Spalding might end up getting what they might deserve but do not want: the loss of important corporate clients.

headline: Ralcorp Got, Rejected Takeover Bid
summary: Ralcorp Holdings said its board received and rejected a takeover offer in March. It didn't disclose the identity of the bidder.

headline: Is Fist-Pumping the Right Reaction?
summary: The 9/11 attacks were arguably the defining and darkest moment for a generation. But the fist-pumping at the news of bin Laden's death left Ralph Gardner concerned.

summary: Entrepreneurs are unsure of them, and venture capitalists dislike them. Corporate venture capitalists are not that scary, says Pradeep Tagare, and provides a useful cheat sheet on how to deal with them.

headline: Death Raises Calls for Afghan Pullout
summary: The death of Osama bin Laden reinforced calls in Afghanistan for a quicker pullout of U.S. troops and, some officials in Washington said, could hasten the shift toward a less troop-intensive U.S. mission.

headline: Pendulum Swings Back Toward Detroit
summary: The successful restructuring of Detroit's auto makers, a group whose survival was in question just two years ago, and the March 11 earthquake in Japan are combining to reverse the fortunes of the U.S. and Japanese auto industries.

headline: Group Seeks Upgrade for Black Boxes
summary: The International Civil Aviation Organization said it wants to make the digital flight data and cockpit-voice recorders of commercial aircraft easier to find after an accident.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications

headline: Sudden Silver Plunge Erases Rally
summary: Two weeks of gains in the silver market were erased in 11 minutes as investors sought to avoid higher trading costs and cash out of a historic rally.

summary: The Internet surged with conversation about the death of Osama bin Laden, cementing social-media sites' growing roles as disseminators of breaking news and as public squares where people discuss it.

summary: Unlike virtual reality's made-up world, augmented reality adds graphics and sound to real-life places and scenes. Katherine Boehret offers a peek into this tech trend.

headline: Knoxville's 'Villa Collina'
summary: This 36,000-square-foot home, modeled after an Italian villa, sits on 12 acres overlooking the Tennessee River and the Great Smoky Mountains.

headline: Are the Better-Off Paying Their Fair Share of Taxes?
summary: Reading Jack Kinstlinger's letter under the headline "We Rich Don't Pay Enough Taxes" (April 29) reveals so much of what is wrong with America.

headline: Mugabe Backs Constitution Project
summary: President Robert Mugabe, known for fiery speeches and the arrests of his critics, is quietly backing a project to craft a new constitution that would extend Zimbabwe's shaky coalition government and provide a reprieve for a nation fearful of the bloodshed that could return with new elections.
